text: The :is() pseudo is a great thing. But unfortunately it’s still not supported by all browsers. Some don’t support it at all, some only support the depricated former version :any() and some only support the former version -webkit-any:(). So yes, great way to keep ones css clean, but unforunately not really usefull yet. At least if you want to support most commonly used browsers.

Sharing for awareness: <https://www.wordfence.com/blog/2021/03/php-compromised-what-wordpress-users-need-to-know|https://www.wordfence.com/blog/2021/03/php-compromised-what-wordpress-users-need-to-know>

This does not impact HubSpot hosted sites. I know though many in the community also develop wordpress websites which do rely on PHP.

Update: evidently the code didn't make it to production so no need to panic.

wow, thats worrying! - I think technically even if it did make it to production it would’ve only impacted people building from source - which isn’t a small thing, but most people are generally using apt-get/yum which is pegged in most cases to stable versions.

But it’s fantastic talking point - PHP is used by a significant portion of the web. A parallel to draw is that a lot of people on HubSpot will be using CDN’s to include things like jQuery and libraries from cdnjs, etc.

Make sure you’re pulling these libraries locally. Checksums/integrity do work but not on all browsers. These CDN services are high reward targets for hackers (even state sponsored) and it’s incredibly simple to just remove that dependency.
